sub_topic: Probability of a certain event occurring in a given time period
message_1: A car dealership sells an average of 30 cars per week. What is the probability that they will sell 40 or more cars in a given week, assuming that the number of cars sold per week follows a normal distribution with a mean of 30 and a standard deviation of 8?
message_2:
To find the probability of selling 40 or more cars in a given week, we need to calculate the z-score and then find the area under the normal distribution curve to the right of that z-score.

The z-score formula is:

z = (X - μ) / σ

where X is the value we want to find the probability for (40 cars), μ is the mean (30 cars), and σ is the standard deviation (8 cars).

z = (40 - 30) / 8
z = 10 / 8
z = 1.25

Now, we need to find the area under the normal distribution curve to the right of z = 1.25. We can use a z-table or an online calculator to find the area to the left of z = 1.25 and then subtract it from 1 to find the area to the right.

P(Z > 1.25) = 1 - P(Z < 1.25)

Using a z-table or an online calculator, we find that P(Z < 1.25) ≈ 0.8944.

P(Z > 1.25) = 1 - 0.8944
P(Z > 1.25) ≈ 0.1056

So, the probability that the car dealership will sell 40 or more cars in a given week is approximately 10.56%.
